page.title: 10Inner Dundrum Bay
page.content: This area is the remnant of the lagoon which was formed behind the gravel ridges and sand dunes in post-glacial times. The Bay is completely tidal (full at high tide, empty at low) except for the courses of the two rivers which flow out through the main channel. The Blackstaff River enters the Inner Bay from the North and the Carrigs enters from the South. Both rivers follow a meandering and constantly shifting course through the mud and silt flats of the Bay. At low tide the bay provides a large feeding area for waders and wildfowl. At high tide, the swans congregate in large numbers around Keel Point. The causeway and bridge at Keel Point provide good fishing in the tide race which inevitably accompanies each tide change.
